title: Patriots get bad news with injuries ahead of Bucs matchup
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson missed Wednesday practice due to hamstring and toe injuries respectively.
Veteran center Garrett Bradbury and linebacker Christian Elliss were non-participants, affecting both the offensive and defensive lines.
Rookies TreVeyon Henderson and Kyle Williams may play key roles if Stevenson and Boutte remain sidelined.

title: Boston youth baseball coach pleads not guilty to drug trafficking charge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Bryan Mejia, 31, a Boston youth baseball coach, pleaded not guilty to a felony fentanyl trafficking charge.
Mejia allegedly sold fentanyl to an undercover officer and was part of a trafficking organization in Massachusetts.
Mejia was released on personal recognizance and will appear in court again for a hearing on December 1.

title: Education technology company to close Boston headquarters, embrace fully remote workplace
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Cengage Group, based in Boston since 2014, will close its Boston headquarters to adopt a fully remote work model.
The company is closing offices on 3 Center Plaza and 200 Pier 4 Blvd, along with sites in Detroit and Cincinnati.
Cengage, serving 90 million students worldwide, will retain its Kentucky office and focus on integrating AI in learning platforms.

title: What Patriots players did during their off day that impressed Mike Vrabel
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: 41 New England Patriots players conducted a workout at Gillette Stadium during their day off on Tuesday.
Head Coach Mike Vrabel praised the dedication shown by players lifting weights despite a busy NFL schedule.
The team's commitment and focus amid a 7-2 record impress Coach Vrabel as the Patriots seek AFC contention.

title: Officials identify two killed in apparent murder-suicide in Beverly
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Becky Lynn Center, 58, and John Patrick Nesbitt, 56, were found dead on Colonial Drive, Beverly, in an apparent murder-suicide.
The victims were discovered with gunshot wounds; police arrived at the scene around 9:40 p.m. Monday.
The Essex County DA's Office, Beverly police, and Massachusetts State Police are investigating the incident.

title: South Boston man linked to Bulger sentenced to 15 years for involvement in 1984, 1993 cold case killings
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Michael Lewis, 65, was sentenced to 15 years for manslaughter in two Massachusetts cold case killings from 1984 and 1993.
Lewis, linked to James 'Whitey' Bulger, pleaded guilty after murder charges were reduced through a plea agreement with prosecutors.
Victims Brian Watson and William Villani were killed in drug-related incidents; Watson's case reached closure nearly 40 years later.

title: Olney: Red Sox ‘well-positioned’ to try and trade for Tigers ace Tarik Skubal
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox are eyeing a trade for Detroit Tigers' ace Tarik Skubal, potentially enhancing their pitching rotation.
Tarik Skubal led the AL in ERA (2.21) and WHIP (0.891) in 2025 and could enter free agency after 2026.
Boston may trade assets like Jarren Duran or Marcelo Mayer to secure Skubal, who is sought by multiple teams.

title: Judge temporarily halts patron saint statues in Quincy, but PETA wants to help
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A judge has temporarily halted Quincy's installation of two patron saint statues due to legal and transparency concerns.
PETA proposes to help fund statues if a third one of St. Francis of Assisi is added for animal patronage.
The ACLU filed a lawsuit against Quincy, and a judge granted a preliminary injunction against the statue plans.

title: Bill Belichick commends Drake Maye for an ‘outstanding’ start with Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick praises Patriots QB Drake Maye for his strong performance and contribution to New England's 7-2 record.
Maye is in MVP contention with DraftKings giving him the third-best odds behind Josh Allen and Patrick Mahomes.
Drake Maye has completed 74.1% of passes for 2,285 yards, 17 touchdowns, and rushed for 270 yards this season.

title: Here’s how many people visited Salem this past Halloween
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Salem attracted 96,000 visitors on Halloween Day, a 7.2% increase from the previous year, despite rain and a government shutdown.
Overall, October saw 1.1 million unique visitors, matching last year's record total, though total visits decreased by 6.3%.
Local organizations ensured key events continued and facilities remained open despite closures due to the government shutdown.
